content:
"In framing a government which is to be administered by men over men, the great difficulty lies in this: you must first enable the government to control the governed; and in the next place oblige it to control itself."

— James Madison, Federalist No. 51, 1788

Two American citizens are dead.

Renee Good was thirty-seven years old, a poet and a mother of three. On January 7 in Minneapolis, she drove to her own street to stand witness during a federal enforcement operation. Video shows a federal agent approaching her vehicle with a pistol in one hand and a phone in the other. As her car turned away, he fired through the windshield, then through the open window at close range. She was pronounced dead within the hour.

Today, seventeen days later, another American citizen was killed in the same city during a federal operation. A lawful gun owner. A valid permit to carry. No criminal record. The Mayor of Minneapolis states he viewed video showing multiple masked federal agents beating the man before shooting him while he was on the ground.

In both cases, federal authorities declared the killings justified within hours.

No independent investigation had occurred. No external authority had reviewed the evidence. No process outside the executive chain that authorized the force had begun.

We were told to wait.

Officials called the first death a “tragedy of her own making.” They labeled her a terrorist. They declared the agent’s actions lawful. After the second killing, federal authorities again declared the shots “defensive,” and suggested the victim had invited his own death by lawfully carrying a firearm.

These were not calls for patience. They were verdicts.

A review that begins only after the state has declared itself innocent is not accountability.

It is a ceremony.

In a republic, force is restrained before it is used. Law precedes violence. Independent oversight precedes explanation. When the state kills first and explains later, consent has already been displaced.

This is no longer a question of intent. It is a question of structure.

Two killings. Seventeen days. The same city. The same declarations of innocence before any independent review.

This is not an anomaly.

It is a policy.

A government that kills its citizens and then investigates itself is not asking for trust. It is testing how much force it may use before resistance returns.

And we are told to wait.
